title: Synthetic Recap
body:
BOSTON (AP) – The night belonged to one man, and his name was Chris Webber. In a virtuoso performance that etched his name into the franchise record books, Webber single-handedly dismantled the Boston Celtics, carrying the Washington Bullets to a resounding 105-92 victory.

From the opening tip, it was clear Webber was on a different plane. He was an unstoppable force, a whirlwind of power and finesse that the Celtics had no answer for. When the final horn sounded, the stat sheet told a story of pure domination: a career-high and Bullets franchise-record 45 points, a Herculean 23 rebounds, and 5 assists. He didn't just play the game; he commanded it, owning both painted areas with an authority that left Boston defenders in his wake.

While the Celtics relied on a more balanced, albeit futile, attack with Antoine Walker’s 20 points and Rick Fox’s 17, their efforts were mere background noise to the Webber symphony. Every time Boston threatened to close the gap, Webber answered. A thunderous dunk in traffic, a silky jumper from the elbow, a relentless put-back—his responses were as varied as they were decisive.

This was more than just a win; it was a historic declaration. On this night in 1997, Chris Webber wasn’t just the best player on the floor; he was a force of nature, delivering a performance for the ages that propelled his team and left an indelible mark on the legacy of the Washington Bullets. The record books will forever show this night as his.
